prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 2
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 3
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A scholar sent to Britain by the Japanese government to further his study of English. He's the defendant accused of attempted murder.
Character 4
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 5
Name: Maid → Joan Garrideb
Description: A maid who works at the Garrideb household. Her main duty appears to be standing at Mr Garrideb's side pouring tea.
Character 6
Name: John Garrideb
Description: A retired army man who's the landlord of the lodgings rented by the defendant, Mr Natsume. An old knee injury means he's confined to a chair most of the time.
Character 7
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous 'great detective'. Not a person except me, apparently.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey, though concrete details of the man are not forthcoming.
Character 9
Name: Olive Green
Description: The victim of this case, who was found with a knife in her back. Luckily, the wound didn't prove fatal, but the woman remains unconscious in her hospital bed.
Character 10
Name: Roly Beate
Description: A devoted London bobby who witnessed the incident whilst walking down the street with his wife of a year, Patricia.
Character 11
Name: Patricia Beate
Description: The wife of Constable Roly Beate who is a witness to the incident. She's relatively recently married, and fiercely proud of her policeman husband.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Local Map
Description: A street map of the local area showing where the victim was found. A street map of the local area showing locations that are relevant to the case.
Evidence 2
Name: Iris's Postcard
Description: A card for Inspector Gregson with a message on the back from Iris.
Evidence 3
Name: Secondhand Book Receipt
Description: A receipt discovered in Mr Natsume's room for some books that he had purchased from a secondhand bookshop before the incident occurred.
Evidence 4
Name: Case File
Description: A file containing an overview of the case and details about the victim. She was found with a knife in her back and is currently in hospital, yet to regain consciousness. The pavement where the victim was found lies just outside Constable Beate's beat, the border of which runs down the middle of Briar Road.
Evidence 5
Name: Jackknife
Description: A large but commonplace folding knife. It was found lodged in the victim's back.
Evidence 6
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the scene taken by a policeman just after the incident occurred. A large knife can be seen thrust into the victim's back.
Evidence 7
Name: Crime Scene Photograph #2
Description: A second photograph of the scene taken by a policeman just after the incident. It specifically shows the victim's hand.
Evidence 8
Name: The Fourth Book
Description: A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' discovered in the victim's hand at the scene. A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' discovered in the victim's hand at the scene. The back cover is badly burnt. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining the burnt corner on the back before it is specifically pointed out in court.) A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' that was in the victim's hand when Mrs Beate first ran over to see what had happened.
Evidence 9
Name: Warrant Card
Description: A small folding wallet that identifies London bobbies and contains the rules of conduct to which they must adhere.
Evidence 10
Name: Anniversary Bouquet
Description: A present for Patricia Beate from her husband, Roly. The shock of seeing the stabbed victim caused Mrs Beate to drop the rose where she stood.
Evidence 11
Name: Pipe
Description: Mr Garrideb's pipe. Apparently it fell to the floor during a domestic dispute he had with his wife and broke.
Evidence 12
Name: Fragment of Metal
Description: This small piece of metal looks like it might be the tip of a knife blade. It was stuck inside the bowl of Mr Garrideb's pipe.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: As I said, it was five o'clock in the afternoon when the incident occurred. And there was an unusually light fog.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 1
Testimony: Visibility was reasonably good, and there was no one else about but the victim and the accused.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 2
Testimony: Out of the blue, the victim was stabbed from behind and subsequently collapsed on the pavement.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 3
Testimony: The accused ran off, scatterin' his belongings all over the floor.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 4
Testimony: Those bein' a number of old books he'd just bought. He was on his way home from a bookshop, it seems.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 5
Testimony: He was on his way home from Bourbon Books, a secondhand bookshop he apparently patronises.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 6
Testimony: It was just a matter of workin' out who the books belonged to, and we found the bloke to arrest him.
Person: Gregson

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let me start by going through the testimonies and the evidences one by one.

First, the testimonies are all from Gregson. Testimony 0 says the incident happened at 5 PM with light fog. Testimony 1 mentions visibility was good, and only the victim and accused were around. Testimony 2 states the victim was stabbed from behind and collapsed. Testimony 3 says the accused ran off, scattering belongings. Testimony 4 and 5 mention the books bought from Bourbon Books, a secondhand shop. Testimony 6 is about identifying the books to arrest him.

Now looking at the evidences. Evidence 3 is a receipt from a secondhand bookshop found in Natsume's room. That aligns with Testimony 4 and 5. Evidence 8 is the book "The Lion's Pride" found in the victim's hand. The description says it was there when Mrs. Beate first ran over. 

Wait, Testimony 3 says the accused (Natsume) ran off, scattering his belongings. But if the book was found in the victim's hand, that suggests the book was with the victim, not scattered by Natsume. The receipt (Evidence 3) shows Natsume bought books, which should be his belongings. But the book in the victim's hand (Evidence 8) might not be his. So if Gregson's Testimony 3 says the accused scattered his books, but the victim was holding one of those books, there's a contradiction. Because if the books were scattered by Natsume when he ran, how did one end up in the victim's hand? Unless the book in her hand wasn't his. But according to Evidence 8, it's "discovered in the victim's hand at the scene" and was there when Mrs. Beate arrived. So if the accused dropped his books while fleeing, but the victim already had the book in her hand when she was attacked, that's a contradiction. Therefore, Evidence 8 (the book in victim's hand) contradicts Testimony 3 (accused scattered belongings, which include the books). Because if the victim was holding the book when she was attacked, the accused couldn't have dropped it while fleeing after the stabbing. The timeline doesn't add up. The accused would have had to drop the books while fleeing, but the victim was already holding one of them when she was stabbed. So the testimony says the books were scattered when he ran off, but the evidence shows the book was in the victim's hand at the time of the stabbing. Therefore, they can't both be true.

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 2
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 3
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A scholar sent to Britain by the Japanese government to further his study of English. He's the defendant accused of attempted murder.
Character 4
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 5
Name: Maid → Joan Garrideb
Description: A maid who works at the Garrideb household. Her main duty appears to be standing at Mr Garrideb's side pouring tea.
Character 6
Name: John Garrideb
Description: A retired army man who's the landlord of the lodgings rented by the defendant, Mr Natsume. An old knee injury means he's confined to a chair most of the time.
Character 7
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous 'great detective'. Not a person except me, apparently.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey, though concrete details of the man are not forthcoming.
Character 9
Name: Olive Green
Description: The victim of this case, who was found with a knife in her back. Luckily, the wound didn't prove fatal, but the woman remains unconscious in her hospital bed.
Character 10
Name: Roly Beate
Description: A devoted London bobby who witnessed the incident whilst walking down the street with his wife of a year, Patricia.
Character 11
Name: Patricia Beate
Description: The wife of Constable Roly Beate who is a witness to the incident. She's relatively recently married, and fiercely proud of her policeman husband.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Local Map
Description: A street map of the local area showing where the victim was found. A street map of the local area showing locations that are relevant to the case.
Evidence 2
Name: Iris's Postcard
Description: A card for Inspector Gregson with a message on the back from Iris.
Evidence 3
Name: Secondhand Book Receipt
Description: A receipt discovered in Mr Natsume's room for some books that he had purchased from a secondhand bookshop before the incident occurred.
Evidence 4
Name: Case File
Description: A file containing an overview of the case and details about the victim. She was found with a knife in her back and is currently in hospital, yet to regain consciousness. The pavement where the victim was found lies just outside Constable Beate's beat, the border of which runs down the middle of Briar Road.
Evidence 5
Name: Jackknife
Description: A large but commonplace folding knife. It was found lodged in the victim's back.
Evidence 6
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the scene taken by a policeman just after the incident occurred. A large knife can be seen thrust into the victim's back.
Evidence 7
Name: Crime Scene Photograph #2
Description: A second photograph of the scene taken by a policeman just after the incident. It specifically shows the victim's hand.
Evidence 8
Name: The Fourth Book
Description: A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' discovered in the victim's hand at the scene. A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' discovered in the victim's hand at the scene. The back cover is badly burnt. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining the burnt corner on the back before it is specifically pointed out in court.) A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' that was in the victim's hand when Mrs Beate first ran over to see what had happened.
Evidence 9
Name: Warrant Card
Description: A small folding wallet that identifies London bobbies and contains the rules of conduct to which they must adhere.
Evidence 10
Name: Anniversary Bouquet
Description: A present for Patricia Beate from her husband, Roly. The shock of seeing the stabbed victim caused Mrs Beate to drop the rose where she stood.
Evidence 11
Name: Pipe
Description: Mr Garrideb's pipe. Apparently it fell to the floor during a domestic dispute he had with his wife and broke.
Evidence 12
Name: Fragment of Metal
Description: This small piece of metal looks like it might be the tip of a knife blade. It was stuck inside the bowl of Mr Garrideb's pipe.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: This case has nothing to do with Mr and Mrs Garrideb. Believe me, a London bobby is good for his word!
Person: Roly
Testimony 1
Testimony: You see - SAH! - the windows on the top floor of the Garrideb house are top-hinged casements.
Person: Roly
Testimony 2
Testimony: Obviously, if anything had been thrown out of the window, we would have seen it.
Person: Patricia
Testimony 3
Testimony: I did leave the scene to go and fetch help, but my trusty Roly was there to make sure nothing was disturbed.
Person: Patricia
Testimony 4
Testimony: I know what I saw. My eyes never let me down! ...My sense of direction is a little off sometimes, though.
Person: Patricia
Testimony 5
Testimony: What happened was, I dropped my bouquet and ended up losing my way for a while.
Person: Patricia
Testimony 6
Testimony: I didn't take my eye off the crime scene for one moment, sah! Nothing strange to report on that front, sah!
Person: Roly

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. The user wants me to find which evidence contradicts which testimony. So I need to look through all the evidence and testimonies to spot inconsistencies.

First, let me list out the testimonies and the evidences. The key is to find a testimony that says something that doesn't align with the evidence provided.

Looking at the testimonies, Testimony 3 by Patricia says she left the scene to fetch help but her husband Roly stayed to make sure nothing was disturbed. Then Testimony 6 from Roly claims he didn't take his eye off the crime scene for a moment. But there's Evidence 10, the Anniversary Bouquet, which Patricia dropped when she saw the victim. The bouquet was dropped where she stood, which would be at the crime scene. However, if Patricia left to get help, how did her bouquet end up there? Wait, but maybe that's not the contradiction.

Another angle: The Crime Scene Photograph #2 (Evidence 7) shows the victim's hand holding the book 'The Lion's Pride' (Evidence 8). The Fourth Book's description mentions it was in the victim's hand when Mrs. Beate (Patricia) first ran over. But according to Testimony 3, Patricia left to get help, implying she was there initially. However, if the book was in the victim's hand when Patricia arrived, and the evidence says that, but Patricia's testimony says she left, maybe there's something there. Wait, maybe not directly.

Looking at Testimony 2 by Patricia: She says that if anything had been thrown out of the window (top floor of Garrideb's house), they would have seen it. But Evidence 12 is a fragment of metal stuck in Mr. Garrideb's pipe. The pipe (Evidence 11) broke during a domestic dispute. The fragment is a knife tip. If the knife was thrown from the window, but Patricia says they would have seen it, but the fragment in the pipe suggests the knife broke there. So if the knife part is in the pipe inside the house, it wasn't thrown out. Maybe that's not a contradiction. Wait, the knife used in the crime was found in the victim's back (Evidence 5). The fragment in the pipe might be part of the same knife. So if the knife was broken in the Garrideb house (as per the pipe fragment), but the main part was found at the crime scene, that implies the knife was broken there. But Patricia and Roly's testimonies (Testimony 2 and 0) say nothing was thrown from the window. So maybe the broken knife tip in the pipe suggests the knife was broken inside the house, hence the fragment is there. But the main knife was found at the crime scene. That would mean the knife was used in the house, broken, then the blade taken outside to stab the victim. But the testimonies say they didn't see anything thrown out. So if the knife was broken inside, but the blade ended up outside, then perhaps the blade was taken out through another means, not thrown from the window. But how does that contradict the testimony? The testimony says if anything was thrown, they would have seen it. So if the blade wasn't thrown, but taken out another way, there's no contradiction. Hmm.

Wait, let's look at Testimony 3: Patricia left to get help, but Roly stayed. Testimony 6: Roly says he didn't take his eyes off the scene. But Evidence 10 is the bouquet Patricia dropped. If Patricia was there initially, dropped the bouquet when the incident happened, then left to get help, but Roly stayed. However, the bouquet being at the scene might indicate that Patricia was present when the incident happened, which she was. But maybe the contradiction is elsewhere.

Another possibility: Evidence 8 (The Fourth Book) says that the book was in the victim's hand when Mrs. Beate (Patricia) first ran over. However, Testimony 5 from Patricia says she dropped her bouquet and lost her way. If she lost her way, how did she immediately run over to the victim? Or maybe the timeline is conflicting. Wait, Testimony 5 says she dropped the bouquet and lost her way, but Testimony 3 says she left to get help. The fact that the bouquet was dropped at the scene suggests she was there initially. The contradiction might be that Patricia claims she left to get help (Testimony 3), but the bouquet was left at the scene. But that's not a contradiction. She could have dropped it when she first arrived, then left. 

Wait, maybe the key is in Testimony 6 where Roly says he didn't take his eyes off the scene, so nothing was disturbed. But Evidence 7 (Crime Scene Photograph #2) shows the victim's hand, which is holding the book. If the book was taken by the victim when Patricia first ran over, but Roly was watching, then the book would be there. But maybe the fact that the book's back cover is burnt (as per the updated description in Evidence 8) wasn't noticed by the police, which could imply something else. Not sure.

Alternatively, Testimony 2 by Patricia says if anything was thrown out the window, they would have seen it. But Evidence 12 is a fragment of metal in the pipe, which might be part of the knife. If the knife was broken in the house (as per the pipe fragment), and the blade was then used in the crime, then the blade had to leave the house. But if they didn't see anything thrown out, how did the blade get there? Maybe someone carried it out, but that's not a direct contradiction. 

Wait, looking at Testimony 0 by Roly: "This case has nothing to do with Mr and Mrs Garrideb." But Evidence 12 (Fragment of Metal) is found in Mr. Garrideb's pipe. The fragment is part of the knife, which connects the Garridebs to the case. Therefore, Testimony 0 claims the Garridebs aren't involved, but Evidence 12 shows a fragment from a knife (same as the murder weapon) in their house. That would contradict Roly's statement. So Evidence 12 and Testimony 0. 

Yes, that makes sense. Roly (Testimony 0) says the Garridebs aren't involved, but the metal fragment in Mr. Garrideb's pipe (Evidence 12) suggests otherwise. Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 12 and Testimony 0.
